Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a multifunctional far-field nanoscopic measurement system for multidisciplinary research

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1040227
Wang

The objective of this proposal is to develop a multifunctional far-field nanoscopic platform based on stimulated emission depletion (STED) and laser induced fluorescence photobleaching anemometer (LIFPA), which will enable the development of nanovelocimeter, nanothermometer and nanofluorescence spectroscopy respectively for measurement of spatial distributions of flow velocity, temperature and concentration in nanofluidics and near-wall flow within 100 nm. STED is applied to break diffraction limit to achieve high spatial resolution and molecular tracer based LIFPA is used to overcome issues with nanoparticles as flow tracer in nanochannel. Currently this team is one of few groups in the world that have the extensive experience in developing sophisticated STED system for nanophotonics application. They have recently developed, for the first time, a far-field non-invasive nanovelocimeter built upon single wavelength continuous wave (cw) laser STED and LIFPA for velocity profile measurement in a subnanometer channel.

However, due to limited resources, the current spatial resolution is limited to 70 nm and the system can be used for few dyes and proteins. The system is difficult for non-expert users. To further advance this technology, they propose to develop a novel system having tunable pulse lasers integrated with confocal microscope, so that the spatial resolution of the system can be ~ 5-10 nm. It will have more functions and broad applications and is easy to use. The proposed instrumentation will rely on existing interdisciplinary collaborative efforts from the College of Engineering and Computing, College of Art and Science, and the School of Medicine.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of South Carolina at Columbia

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
With NSF's MRI support, we have developed a large sophisticated, multifunctional, far field nanoscopic 3-D measuring system. This nanoscopy is an integration of multifunctional system. It enables measurement of fluid flow velocity, temperature and concentration in microfluidics and nanofluidics with unprecedented simultaneously high spatial and temporal resolution. The system is based on Stimulated Emission Depletion (STED) that can overcome diffraction limit in physics to significantly increase spatial resolution in imaging, and measurement in micro/nanofluidics. The home-developed instrument manly consist of two femto lasers and a laser Scanning Confocal Microscope System. The system also includes laser induced fluorescence photobleaching anemometer (LIFPA) developed recently to overcome the drawbacks of velocimeters that uses particles as flow tracers for micro/nanofluidics.  

STED and LIFPA each has its uniqueness and can be applied to many fields. Combination of STED nanoscopy and LIFPA technique can be applied to multidisciplinary fields, such as nanoscopic velocimeter for micro/nanofluidics and interfacial flows, ultrafast and nanoscopic measurment, fluorescence spectroscopy, cellular imaging and nanofabrication. The new system will enable fundamental research. For instance, with LIFPA we can measure highly fluctuated flow in microchannels and recently for the first time find astonishingly there can be turbulence in a microchannel with Reynolds number on the order of only unity in an electrokinetically excited pressure driven flow. This unique interdisciplinary capacity will complement and enhance many research activities and promote interdisciplinary collaboration.

 


Last Modified: 12/07/2015
Modified by: Guiren Wang

This nanoscopy is an integration of multifunctional system. The system also includes laser induced fluorescence photobleaching anemometer (LIFPA) developed recently to overcome the drawbacks of velocimeters that uses particles as flow tracers for micro/nanofluidics. STED and LIFPA each has its uniqueness and can be applied to many fields. Combination of STED nanoscopy and LIFPA technique can be applied to multidisciplinary fields, such as nanoscopic velocimeter for micro/nanofluidics and interfacial flows, ultrafast and nanoscopic measurment, fluorescence spectroscopy, cellular imaging and nanofabrication. The new system will enable fundamental research.
